ratings.comment: Tim's a very nice guy who's passionate about environmental sustainability, but his lectures need a rewrite. There's an incredible amount of slides per lecture (115ish) most of which don't add anything to the class. He loves a tangent while skipping the important parts of lecture while going heavy on small topics. Easy grading, labs were busywork.

If you're genuinely interested in diving deep into the carbon cycle, learning about energy use on campus, or need a science credit, I wouldn't particularly write off this class as a bad option. Tim is a great professor, but be warned that TAs were not very helpful, at least this past semester. Lecture attendance isn't mandatory, said Tim on Day 1.

Tim is nice but isn't great at lecturing. We'd often fall behind during lectures as Tim went on and on about current events at the University which is entirely negative but doesn't need to take 20-30 minutes of class. The class just felt like a waste of time and the labs had very little to do with the lecture (The TAs also did very little in lab).

I had Tim for a 1 credit seminar and he was a very kind and caring instructor. We had weekly meetings and he expressed interest in our lives and in our discussions. He put a lot of time into helping us create connections with other professors and members of the community. I am extremely thankful for him and I would definitely recommend him.

Nothing bad to say. Tim is kind, funny, and caring. He is clearly passionate about the material. He was always willing to help his students, as were the TAs. Labs could get lengthy, but overall an easy science course.

As far as Professor Lindstrom goes, no complaints - funny guy, explained concepts in attainable ways, and you can tell he's passionate about environmental science. Slides are always posted. The class itself can be a bit boring, labs are essentially just long worksheets and are graded harshly imo, but easy science credit for a non-science person.

Great guy: DONOT take this class unless you have to. Each week there are 20+ page labs that are repetitive. You can find the answers on lecture slides but it is time consuming. Class focuses on how campus facilities run. Lots of field trips to them. Grades don't get put in until finals week and they grade hardest on exams (Unclear expectations)
This class is the biggest waste of time ever.

Great lecturer overall and very kind! If you have the chance to take his class, I highly recommend doing so. Some of the labs are a bit long and have a lot of information, but they aren't bad! Great TAs as well.
I loved this class! It was very easy and all the instructors really tried hard to make you succeed. Class was boring and busy work at times but as a non science person this was really great.

While the class itself could be a bit hit or miss at times, Professor Lindstrom, and the TAs, were a delight throughout. Very passionate about what he's teaching and you can really tell how much he loves the class and the subject. Lab component of the class is honestly a bit unnecessary, but if you need a class w/ a lab this one is a good pick.

Best professor I have this semester. He cares SO MUCH about what he is teaching, and has genuinely interesting that lectures go by fast. He also has the cutest little outfits, and cares about his students a lot. The TAs are amazing as well. If you need help with anything, you will get it as long as you ask. Class load is not too hard, free food.

The class is really easy for a lab science. Two homeworks a week, consistently due at midnight on Tuesday and Thursday. The Thursday assignment is the previous week's lab (you have a week to do it) which is nice. Kind of pointless/busywork but Tim is the goat and also is a big sweetie. I hate science but Tim makes it bearable. Live love Tim.

Tim is one of the best profs I've had at UW. He is passionate about the material, his lectures are engaging, he cares about his students both as students and as people, and he explains concepts very well. The class is not a lot of work, but I still learned a lot. I almost wish he made more of the optional work mandatory. Important subject matter!

Probably the most pointless class of my undergrad. Every assignment is just busywork, and there are a lot of them. If you're actually interested in learning useful information, take a different class. Grades from week 2 on didn't get entered until finals week

This is by far the easiest science class I have ever taken. I took this as an honors-only class and there was a non honors section that met at the same time and there was absolutely no extra work involved. I would recommend this class to everyone that needs science credits or is just interested in sustainability. I do not have one complaint to give

Tim tries his best to make lectures engaging and make the information as applicable as possible. There were lots of assignments, but Tim and the TAs were always willing to help on them. I would reccommend this class for non-science majors. Watch the lectures, go to lab, and you will do well!

Tim is my favorite professor. His lectures are very engaging and he give directs answers to weekly quizzes. He does a great job of actually teaching and embedding the content into real life experiences (sustainability, energy use ect.) so there's no need for memorization or anything like that. Exams were easy too. Would take again!
